section.title: Release Notes
section.para: This section outlines important details about the release, including recommended practices and notable changes to Red Hat CloudForms. You must take this information into account to ensure the best possible outcomes for your deployment.

listitem.para: The new version of CloudForms Management Engine now allows Red Hat Enterprise Linux OpenStack Platform events use in policies. Previously Red Hat Enterprise Linux OpenStack Platform events could only be captured in either the policy log or by alerts.

This enhancement adds support for using the Subscription Asset Manager (SAM) Account Name as an alternative to the user principal name when authenticating against Active Directory. This enables users to use their SAM account name in environments, using the SAM account name in place of the user's principal name for authentication.

Red Hat CloudForms ships with a core set of Ruby gems used by the CloudForms Management Engine Rails Application. The Ruby gems in this set are subject to change, and have changed since CloudForms 3.1 (CloudForms Management Engine 5.3). If you are calling gems using Automate that are no longer in the CloudForms Management Engine Appliance, you can install them by using the gem install command.

important.para: Gems that have been installed using the gem install command are not supported by Red Hat.

listitem.para: While gems can be imported into automation methods using require, it is recommended that the authors of the automation methods clearly document the use of gems either in the core set or a custom set. It is the responsibility of the author of such custom automation to own the life cycle of any gem being referenced in those methods.
You can find the list of all gems in the appliance in the /var/www/miq/vmdb/log/gem_list.txt file.

In the current version of CloudForms Management Engine, the operating system part of the QuadIcon for virtual machines hosted on an OpenStack provider is unknown and shown as a question mark. The operating system icon is displayed correctly after smart state analysis has been performed on the instance or virtual machine image.
